name: mr_pete
text: The crime blotter brilliantly anticipated Fark.com.

name: wehavemagnums
text: I get the feeling that people rating this low aren't actually reading it all. Is funny!

name: connellingus
text: A comment left by connellingus was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by silver_lake, Ariamaki, lamelliform, shammack)

name: soticoto
text: A comment left by soticoto was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by 7th_shot, Ariamaki, atticusonline, ColnelPanic)

name: sillis
text:
Thanks for the tip!

I was about to not read it because the font was unreadably small. Turn out operas 'fit to width' (quite usefull on my eeePC) option shrunk this shit too small.

Damn, I forget I'd promised myself not to write any comments, register or anythin for that matter.

name: stuart
text:
tl;dr

(the joke in the obituaries is that two poor seniors with many dead offspring die unceremoniously but a rich man's three month old who sucked a poisonous tit flower is honored like Davy Fucking Crockett)

name: i_love_kate
text: I will not abide such slander against Silas. He was young, yes, but a finer baby you couldn't hope to meet.

name: zouski
text: I thank you for the tl;dr! I did not have to scroll far to find it.

name: capnroblivious
text: Which is unusual for someone having typed "TL;DR."

name: scorpio_nadir
text:
Funny?
Baby Silas was tragically poisoned when an exotic orchid wilted into his crib and the deadly flower was mistaken for a suckling teat.
Gaaahhh.

name: dissembly
text:
I think you might have missed the point.

The overblown, poetic obituary and the nature of the Services contrast with the ones before it, do you not see?

Also note that it is dated from the middle of the Great Depression, thereby underscoring the nature of the Issues raised.

name: petitegitan
text: Oh Immanuel Rutlidge, you crazy bastard.

name: postblank
text: He was so drunk that he felt it was probably illegal.

name: dapooka
text: And obviously not scared of the police if he was crying for arrest.

name: dapooka
text: Misquoting Mr. Bear on nearly my very first post. Lameness.

name: sargasm
text: An early history of cats going crazy in California.  Interesting!

name: zedpower
text: Haha, mailbagging. Hilarious and gruesome.

name: belgand
text: Actually I suspect that it is a method of execution used by the animals at that time. Not the work of Saturday Men or unruly youth as the human blotter would assume.

name: jdhenry105
text: Breakfast soup?

name: confusion
text: Glad someone else noticed that one. Whatever it is, I want some. It's even fun just to say. Breakfast soup. Breakfast soup...

name: foetus_punch
text:
Don't eat breakfast soup, or Poles will laugh at you and ruin your domicile.

Seriously, how were they having an argument if one was actually outside the house? Or am I just making assumptions again.

name: mangtastic
text: Perhaps they had been arguing about the same thing for quite some time?

name: wingspan
text: I somehow don't think a house that can be pushed over by a 51 year old man would be particularly soundproof.

name: kyrasmash
text: Remember that the 51 year old man was a Pole. Wicked strength. That building could have been a cement bunker and would have toppled just as easily.

name: benthecartoon
text: Breakfast Soup, part of Campbell's expanded line, including Heartbreak Soup and Stone Soup.

name: skiddyfisk
text: I, too, skimmed past this strip previously, until just now, having read it in full. Bravo! Also my vote upped its overall rating by a whole .2. Wow.

name: jlowe424
text: Contact with the chums has not been established.

name: ganymedeio
text: I knew someone had to find this as entertaining as I did.

name: mindbnder
text: East Achewood obviously has a storied past of seedy behavior and/or Mailbagging.  No wonder Beef comes from Circumstances.

name: autobahnbismark
text: How is it possible for an 83 year old woman to have children die in the Battle of Jutland or Galipolli?

name: bourbonsamurai
text: grandchildren.

name: ravindra108
text: Perhaps you missed the date of the newspaper? September 8, 1932, which means she was born in 1849. Those grandkids were born in the 1890's, making them the prime age for a terrible death at the hands of WWI.

name: hootplate
text: I note that the two elderly deceased in the strip are cremated by the city, but the infant child dead by negligence has a lavish funeral.

name: ashoykh
text: i even read the whole darn thing

name: xiaomimi
text:
Weekend Blogs

Philippe: I am getting older now so I can have sugar cereal.
Molly: Nowhere to go but Wendy's

name: semiquaver
text: Yay! I can affect the strip's rating! I've been waiting the entire archive for this! Toggles happily between the "4" and "5" buttons

name: speth
text: He blinked several times incredulously as the Pole stood by and laughed.

name: unsentletter
text: The lesson here might be not to fuck with the Poles in East Achewood.

name: charchar
text:
"The accused returned to the church to consume juice and swap impressions of the event."

In the idiom of Southern Baptists, this ritual is referred to as "sharing and fellowshipping." There's my bit of trivia for you guys today.

name: alzuna
text: I think the incident of private drunkenness is my favorite of the list.

name: pogo
text: Gotta try that "mailbagging" soon.

name: orvel
text: Mailbagging bumps this up to a four.

name: johnnyrocker
text:
It is my secret and private theory, (which I will only let out here, where I suspect very few will see it,) that the intelligent animals in Achewood are the result of Achewater consumption, similar to Terrence Mckenna's "stoned ape" theory of evolution.

In the early days, (the 1930s) the intelligent animals were a lot more buck-wild. Luckily for dogs, they have since settled down.

name: echidnaboy
text: The Graham obituary describes a grim tableaux worthy of Edward Gorey.

name: scura
text: one of the best things about this comic is its back story development

name: perilon
text: I love when Chris Onstad teaches me new vocabulary: viz. "doss house," i.e. flophouse.

name: muddgirl
text:
Anyone who has ever read a small-town police blotter would give this strip a 5.

The neighbor sat there, in his garters and shirt, without even his collar, as the dust settled into his breakfast soup.

Classic.

name: sp1derbaby
text: Dark.

name: tekende
text:
I really like the idea of an entire group of grown men tipping over a pedal-car. I mean, really how much effort would that take? A pedal-car can't be much heavier than, say, a tricycle, yes?

Also, was the child riding the car at the time of the incident? Probably not, but it's nice to think so.

name: highfeverblues
text: Try reading these .

name: dasilodavi
text:
Old artifacts of a tragic past are turned to ash and discarded by society. An infant passes away by chance and a library is erected in her honor.

No Justice. No peace.

name: darqhermit
text: I want to drink at the What Cheer saloon

name: dybrar
text: These obituaries are the saddest thing. I am fairly serious about this.

name: aezlo
text: You know, my favorite part of this strip is probably the fact that Mr. Phepps was boozing with his cat. I know there's not a lot of cat/human relations in Achewood, but the idea of a man and his can drowning their sorrows together truly warms my heart.
